_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Sun Pacific Reedley has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Sun Pacific Reedley, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Sun Pacific Reedley has updated/ their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name         |Process Chemical         | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration Anhydrous Ammonia          80,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations

as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

Ito Packing Company operates a commercial cold storage facility in Reedley, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(13) Cold Storage Rooms
(1) Fumigation Room
(4) Precoolers
(3) Hallways
(1) Loading Dock
(1) Liquid Recirculator
(1) Cherry Hydrocooler

The cold storage rooms, precool rooms, fumigation room, loading dock, and hallways are equipped with air-cooling evaporators, and the cherry hydrocooler is equipped with water-cooling evaporator and accumulators as required for flooded operation. The pre-wash hydrocooler is equipped with water-cooling evaporators (bare coils) and a liquid recirculator for a pumped overfeed system.

Most control valve groups are located in the center hall (catwalk) to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within two refrigeration machinery rooms (north and south) or directly above each machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:

North Machinery Room
(2) Mycom N4WB Reciprocating Compressors
(3) Mycom N6WB Reciprocating Compressors
(1) Mycom N8WB Reciprocating Compressor
(2) Mycom N12WB Reciprocating Compressors
(5) 16" Dia. x 4'-0" Vertical Oil Separators
(1) 18" Dia. x 4'-6" Vertical Oil Separators
(2) 20" Dia. x 5'-0" Vertical Oil Separators
(1) 48" Dia. x 10'-0" Horizontal Main Suction Accumulator
(1) 20" Dia. x 2'-6" Vertical Liquid Transfer Vessel

South Machinery Room
(2) Frick RWB II-222 Screw Compressors
(1) FES 23M Screw Compressor
(2) 30" Dia. x 14'-0" Horizontal Oil Separators
(1) 30" Dia. x 13'-4" Horizonta

l Oil Separator
(1) 84" Dia. x 7'-6" Horizontal Main Suction Accumulator
(2) 24" Dia. x 4'-0" Vertical Liquid Transfer Vessels
(1) 20" Dia. x 7'-6" Vertical Thermosyphon Vessel
(1) Armstrong Auto-Purger
(1) 96" Dia. x 45'-0" Horizontal High Pressure Receiver
(1) B.A.C. VXMC-1240 Evaporative Condenser
(1) B.A.C. VLC-900 Evaporative Condenser
(3) B.A.C. C2604 Evaporative Condensers

Loading Dock
(3) Frigid Coil Series 650 AHB 5310 Ceiling Units

Hallways
(7) Frigid Coil Series 650 AHB 5310 Ceiling Units
(1) Frigid Coil AIC-H-518-4-FLA-WD-IP Ceiling Unit
(2) Frigid Coil AIC-3H-5710-4-FL-WD Ceiling Units
(4) Krack DT2-370-FLA Ceiling Units
(3) Frigid Coil AIC-H-5110-4-FLA-WD-IP Ceiling Units

The flooded system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator mounted behind the bunker wall. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to each main suction accumulator on each machinery room roof.  From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the thermosyphon vessel and then to the high pressure receiver.

The pumped overfeed system operates as follows:  high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a series of liquid feed solenoid valves, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator.  From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into e

vaporator.  Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator.  As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator.  The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to a thermosyphon vessel, and from the thermosyphon vessel it returns to the high pressure receiver. High pressure liquid from the thermosyphon vessel is supplied to the oil coolers on each screw compressor. High temperature liquid is evaporated in the oil cooler and a combination of high temperature gas and liquid is returned to the thermosyphon vessel by thermosyphon action.

The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.

The ammonia system at Sun Pacific Reedley consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping.  As such, the refrigeration system at Sun Pacific Reedley is treated as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Ito Packing Company has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of i

nforming the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Sun Pacific Reedley facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 80,000 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of ammonia at Ito Packing in the last 5 years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Sun Pacific Reedley's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR §3220
- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR §1910.38

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 
Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Sun Pacific Reedley has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Sun Pacific Reedley continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have

access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Ito Packing Company's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Ito Packing Company's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Ito Packing Company has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.
In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Ito Packing Company has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Ito Packing Company now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Ito Packing Company employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Ito Packing Company will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
